title: 104_hr1714
content: The Act titled "Endangered Species Relisting Act of 1995" requires a review of species. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require a petition and review process for certain species to be listed as endangered or threatened. After a 12-month period, a covered species must have a petition filed for relisting before being included in any list under the Act. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require a petition and review process for certain species to be listed as endangered or threatened. The Secretary can determine a species to be certain to become extinct within a 24-month period based on the best available scientific and commercial data, subject to a 60-day comment period before taking effect. The Secretary can utilize existing recovery plans for species when making determinations under the Endangered Species Relisting Act of 1995. Determinations must be published in the Federal Register, respond to comments, and are subject to judicial review after a 24-month period. The Endangered Species Relisting Act of 1995 states that once the Secretary determines a species is not endangered or threatened, it will not be listed unless further evaluation is done. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation of this provision. The Endangered Species Relisting Act of 1995 requires the Secretary to report annually to Congress on progress in considering petitions to relist species. A conforming amendment allows for the relisting of a species on the endangered list. A conforming amendment allows for the relisting of a species on the endangered list. SEC. 3. PEER REVIEW REQUIREMENT. Section 4 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include new peer review requirements. The Secretary must not take any action unless data has undergone peer review by at least 3 independent reviewers recommended by the National Academy of Sciences. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include new peer review requirements for data submitted to the Secretary. Actions described include species listing, retention, removal, and recovery plan development. Results of peer reviews must be published by the Secretary. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include new peer review requirements for data submitted to the Secretary. The Secretary must obtain recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences for individuals to perform peer review and consult with appropriate scientific boards for economic analyses. SEC. 4. DEADLINE FOR DEVELOPMENT OF RECOVERY PLANS. Section 4(f) of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require the Secretary to begin developing a recovery plan for a listed species within 30 days of listing and issue the plan within 12 months or provide reasons for the delay to Congress. Any person affected by the listing of a species under subsection (c) may submit a proposed recovery plan to the Secretary. The Secretary shall adopt the final recovery plan that imposes the lowest costs, applies to more than one species, and does not prohibit the use of land or water for other purposes. SEC. 5 INCIDENTAL TAKE IN COURSE OF NORMAL ACTIVITIES. Section 4 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to allow incidental take in certain activities, such as emergency response, facility operations, repairs, and minor construction. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to allow incidental take in specific activities, including land clearing for fire code compliance, agricultural production, protection of human life, and other approved lawful activities by State or local governments.
